<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Loan Loss Provision Recapture
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, we recorded a loan loss provision recapture of $3.7&nbsp;million compared to $2.9&nbsp;million for
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The loan loss provision recapture during 2015 was primarily due to the continued improvement in our loan loss experience, as well as the improved asset quality
	in our loan portfolio as a result of reductions in our problem loans and in the balances of certain loan classes that we believe bear higher risk, such as church and commercial real estate loans. See
	"Allowance for Loan Losses" for additional information.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Non-Interest Income
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Non-interest income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 totaled $2.9&nbsp;million compared to $1.1&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The $1.8&nbsp;million increase in non-interest income during 2015 was primarily due to a gain of $1.8&nbsp;million on the sale of $164.1&nbsp;million of loans in 2015
	compared to a gain of $19&nbsp;thousand on the sale of $3.3&nbsp;million of loans in 2014. We also received a CDFI grant that was
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	34
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=37,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=348749,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DU49801A.;21',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DU49801_1_35">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$155&nbsp;thousand
	larger than the grant that we received in 2014 and recorded $167&nbsp;thousand of income from a settlement of a legal matter involving a customer. These increases more than
	offset the absence of any gain on restructuring of debt in 2015. In 2014, we reported a gain on restructuring of debt of $365&nbsp;thousand, which represented the remaining unamortized deferred gain
	from restructuring our senior debt in 2013, which we recognized as other income, when we paid off the remaining senior debt in October 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Non-Interest Expense
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Non-interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 totaled $13.4&nbsp;million compared to $13.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The $67&nbsp;thousand increase in non-interest expense during 2015 was primarily due to an increase of $1.2&nbsp;million in compensation and benefits expense, primarily
	reflecting a special accrual of $1.2&nbsp;million for a contribution to our ESOP. Our Board declared an additional contribution to the ESOP because it was not able to distribute equity incentives to
	management and employees while the Consent Order was in effect. The Board felt that it was important to reward employees for their performance over the last three years and to create long term equity
	incentives for future performance. This increase was partially offset by a decrease of $413&nbsp;thousand in REO expenses, a decrease of $280&nbsp;thousand in FDIC assessments, a decrease of
	$208&nbsp;thousand in professional services expense, a decrease of $139&nbsp;thousand in other expense and a decrease of $85&nbsp;thousand in office services and supplies expense. The decrease
	in REO expense during 2015 was primarily due to reduced valuation write-downs reflecting fewer foreclosures and more stable property values. The decrease of $280&nbsp;thousand in FDIC assessments
	during 2015 was primarily due to a reduction in our assessment rate. Professional services expense in 2015 was lower than in 2014 due to legal and consulting fees incurred in 2014 in connection with
	negotiating an extension of the maturity of the Debentures. Other expense decreased in 2015 due to lower appraisal expenses, primarily because we have fewer problem loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We recorded an income tax benefit of $4.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to an income tax expense of
	$3&nbsp;thousand for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. Based on our ability to reasonably project taxable income in future years, the income tax benefit for 2015 includes a partial reversal
	of a portion of the valuation allowance. We believe it is more likely than not that a portion of the deferred tax assets will be realized through future taxable income. In addition, approximately
	$3.0&nbsp;million of federal net operating loss carryforwards and $3.0&nbsp;million state net operating loss carryforwards were used to offset current taxable income for 2015. The tax expense for
	2014 included the statutory minimum taxes paid to the state of California, and also reflected the use of net operating loss carryforwards to offset current taxable income in 2014. As of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 we had a remaining valuation allowance on deferred tax assets of $2.5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As
	of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had net deferred tax assets of $4.6&nbsp;million, which includes federal and California net operating loss carryforwards of $11.9&nbsp;million and
	$29.2&nbsp;million, respectively, which begin expiring in 2031 through 2034. See Note&nbsp;1 "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies" and Note&nbsp;11 "Income Taxes" of the Notes to
	Consolidated Financial Statements for a further discussion of income taxes and a reconciliation of income tax at the federal statutory tax rate to actual tax expense (benefit).
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Section&nbsp;382
	of the Internal Revenue Code imposes limitations on a corporation's ability to utilize net operating loss carryforwards, tax credit carryovers and other income tax attributes when
	there is an ownership change. Generally, the rules provide that an ownership change is deemed to have occurred when the cumulative increase of each 5% or more stockholder and certain groups of
	stockholders treated as 5% or more stockholders, as determined under Section&nbsp;382, exceeds 50% over a specified "testing" period, generally equal to three years. Section&nbsp;382 applies rules
	regarding the treatment of new groups of stockholders treated as 5% stockholders due to issuances of stock and other equity transactions, which may cause a change of control to occur. The Company has
	performed an analysis of the potential impact of
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	35
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=38,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=547738,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DU49801A.;21',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DU49801_1_36">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Section&nbsp;382
	and has determined that the Company did not undergo an ownership change during 2015 or 2014 and any potential limitations imposed under Section&nbsp;382 do not currently apply.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Comparison of Financial Condition at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Total Assets
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Total assets were $402.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, which represented an increase of $52.0&nbsp;million, or 15%, from total assets
	of $350.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The growth in assets during 2015, which was funded by deposit growth, was primarily due to changes in loans held for investment, which increased
	$27.5&nbsp;million, and in cash and cash equivalents, which increased $47.0&nbsp;million. The increase of $47.0&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents was due to federal funds sold, part of
	cash and cash equivalents, increasing substantially as a result of the $54.7&nbsp;million growth in deposits. These increases were partially offset by a decrease of $19.5&nbsp;million in loans
	held for sale and a decrease of $2.9&nbsp;million in securities available-for-sale.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Loans Receivable Held for Sale
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We had no loans receivable held for sale at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Loans receivable held for sale at December&nbsp;31, 2014 totaled
	$19.5&nbsp;million and consisted of multi-family loans. During 2015, we transferred $90.2&nbsp;million of multi-family loans from the held-for-investment portfolio to the held-for-sale portfolio
	and allocated $57.7&nbsp;million, or 51%, of our loan originations during 2015 to the held-for-sale portfolio as part of our loan concentration risk management program. We sold $165.7&nbsp;million
	of loans receivable held for sale, including origination costs of $1.6&nbsp;million, and received $1.6&nbsp;million in principal repayments during 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Loans Receivable Held for Investment
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our gross loan portfolio increased by $23.9&nbsp;million to $309.0&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $285.1&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase in our loan portfolio during 2015 primarily consisted of an increase of $91.5&nbsp;million in our single family residential real estate loan portfolio due to
	loan purchases, and a decrease of $53.9&nbsp;million in our multi-family residential real estate loan portfolio due to loan sales. Also, we experienced a reduction of $5.3&nbsp;million in our
	commercial real estate loan portfolio and $8.4&nbsp;million in our church loan portfolio due to principal payoffs.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	For
	the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, loans originated for investment (excluding $57.7&nbsp;million of multi-family loans allocated to held for sale) totaled $55.3&nbsp;million, including
	origination costs of $416&nbsp;thousand, compared to loans originated for investment of $96.1&nbsp;million, including origination costs of $563&nbsp;thousand, for the year ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. Loan purchases, including purchase premiums of $498&nbsp;thousand, totaled $100.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015. In contrast, we did not
	purchase any loans during 2014. Loan repayments totaled $40.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $42.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014.
	Loans transferred to our held-for-sale portfolio totaled $90.2&nbsp;million during 2015 compared to $22.8&nbsp;million during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Gross
	loan charge-offs during 2015 totaled $89&nbsp;thousand, compared to gross loan charge-offs of $693&nbsp;thousand during 2014. Loans transferred to REO during 2015 totaled
	$1.2&nbsp;million, compared to $2.6&nbsp;million during 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Allowance for Loan Losses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We record a provision for loan losses as a charge to earnings when necessary in order to maintain the ALLL at a level sufficient, in management's
	judgment, to absorb probable incurred losses in the loan portfolio. At least quarterly we conduct an assessment of the overall quality of the loan portfolio and general economic trends in the local
	market. The determination of the appropriate level for the allowance
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	36
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=39,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=756602,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DU49801A.;21',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DU49801_1_37">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	is
	based on that review, considering such factors as historical loss experience for each type of loan, the size and composition of our loan portfolio, the levels and composition of our loan
	delinquencies, non-performing loans and net loan charge-offs, the value of underlying collateral on problem loans, regulatory policies, general economic conditions, and other factors related to the
	collectability of loans in the portfolio.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	ALLL decreased to $4.8&nbsp;million, or 1.56% of our gross loans receivable held for investment, at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $8.5&nbsp;million, or 2.97% of our gross loans receivable
	held for investment, at December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily reflecting $3.7&nbsp;million of loan loss provision recapture. The loan portfolio as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 included
	$100.0&nbsp;million of loans purchased for which there was no assigned allowance for loan losses. These loans were purchased at fair value and management has not noticed any deterioration of credit
	quality in these loans since purchase. The reduction in ALLL at December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to December&nbsp;31, 2014, and the loan loss provision recaptures during 2015, reflect the results
	of our quarterly reviews of the adequacy of the ALLL. We continue to maintain our ALLL at a level that we believe is appropriate given the significant reduction in delinquencies and non-performing
	loans, the continued improvement in our asset quality metrics and the high quality of our loan originations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our
	loan delinquencies and non-performing loans are at their lowest levels since December 2009. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had total delinquencies of $1.4&nbsp;million, compared to total
	delinquencies of $2.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease of $1.1&nbsp;million in loan delinquencies during 2015 was primarily due to a loan sale of $857&nbsp;thousand,
	payoffs of $292&nbsp;thousand and transfers to REO of $843&nbsp;thousand. In addition, a delinquent loan in the amount of $455&nbsp;thousand was brought current. These decreases were partially
	offset by $1.4&nbsp;million in new delinquent loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Non-performing
	loans ("NPLs") consist of delinquent loans that are 90&nbsp;days or more past due and other loans, including troubled debt restructurings that do not qualify for accrual status. At
	December&nbsp;31,
	2015, NPLs totaled $4.2&nbsp;million, compared to $8.9&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease of $4.7&nbsp;million in NPLs was primarily due to payoffs of $1.4&nbsp;million,
	transfers to REO of $1.2&nbsp;million, a sale of $857&nbsp;thousand, returns to accrual status of $886&nbsp;thousand, repayments of $544&nbsp;thousand and charge-offs of $89&nbsp;thousand,
	which were partially offset by the placement of a church loan for $394&nbsp;thousand into non-accrual status.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	connection with our review of the adequacy of our ALLL, we track the amount and percentage of our NPLs that are paying currently, but nonetheless must be classified as NPL for reasons unrelated to
	payments, such as lack of current financial information and an insufficient period of satisfactory performance. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, $3.2&nbsp;million, or 76%, of our total NPLs of
	$4.2&nbsp;million were current in their payments. Also, in determining the ALLL, we consider the ratio of the ALLL to NPLs, which increased to 114.22% at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from 95.52% at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	When
	reviewing the adequacy of the ALLL, we also consider the impact of charge-offs, including the changes and trends in loan charge-offs. Gross loan charge-offs during 2015 were $89&nbsp;thousand
	compared to $693&nbsp;thousand during 2014. The charge-offs during 2015 were primarily due to impairment losses on foreclosed church loans and a delinquent single-family residential real estate loan
	that was fully written off. In determining charge-offs, we update our estimates of collateral values on NPLs by obtaining new appraisals at least every nine months. If the estimated fair value of the
	loan collateral less estimated selling costs is less than the recorded investment in the loan, a charge-off for the difference is recorded to reduce the loan to its estimated fair value, less
	estimated selling costs. Therefore, certain losses inherent in our total NPLs are recognized periodically through charge-offs. The impact of updating these estimates of collateral value and
	recognizing any required charge-offs is to increase charge-offs and reduce the ALLL required on these loans. As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had written down 70% of our NPLs to estimated fair value
	less estimated selling costs. The remaining 30% of our NPLs at December&nbsp;31, 2015 were reported at cost because the fair value of collateral less estimated selling costs exceeded the recorded
	investment in the loan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	37
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=40,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=425411,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DU49801A.;21',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DU49801_1_38">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Recoveries
	during 2015 totaled $152&nbsp;thousand and were primarily related to the payoff of a non-accrual single family loan and repayments on B notes which had been fully written off as part of
	the restructured A/B notes. Recoveries during 2014 totaled $1.9&nbsp;million and were primarily due to payoffs of two non-accrual loans secured by church properties and two commercial loans that had
	been fully written off in late 2011 and a settlement of a loan, which had been previously written down, through an exchange for property received in foreclosure, the fair value of which exceeded the
	cost basis of the related loan.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Impaired
	loans at December&nbsp;31, 2015 were $15.8&nbsp;million, compared to $23.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. Specific reserves for impaired loans were $995&nbsp;thousand, or
	6.30% of the aggregate impaired loan amount at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to $1.5&nbsp;million, or 6.40%, at December&nbsp;31, 2014. Excluding
	specific reserves for impaired loans, our coverage ratio (general allowance as a percentage of total non-impaired loans) decreased to 1.31% at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from 2.66% at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. The decrease in our coverage ratio reflected a decline in our historical charge-offs and the continued improvements in our asset quality.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	believe that the ALLL is adequate to cover probable incurred losses in the loan portfolio as of December&nbsp;31, 2015, but there can be no assurance that actual losses will not exceed the
	estimated amounts. In addition, the OCC and the FDIC periodically review the ALLL as an integral part of their examination process. These agencies may require an increase in the ALLL based on their
	judgments of the information available to them at the time of their examinations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Real Estate Owned
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	REO decreased by $1.7&nbsp;million to $360&nbsp;thousand at December&nbsp;31, 2015, from $2.1&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014.
	During 2015, three church loans were foreclosed and the properties securing the loans were transferred to REO at fair values totaling $1.2&nbsp;million. Four REO properties were sold during 2015 for
	net proceeds of $2.9&nbsp;million and a net loss of $45&nbsp;thousand. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Bank's REO consisted of one church building.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Deposits
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Deposits totaled $272.6&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015, up $54.7&nbsp;million from December&nbsp;31, 2014. During 2015, certificates
	of deposit increased by $46.2&nbsp;million and represented 67% and 62% of total deposits at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Core deposits (NOW, demand, money market and passbook
	accounts) increased by $8.5&nbsp;million during 2015 and represented 33% and 38% of total deposits at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. A long-time customer deposited
	$12.5&nbsp;million in his money market and NOW accounts, and opened a $40.0&nbsp;million two-year certificate of deposit during the third quarter of 2015. This relationship accounted for
	approximately 17% of our deposits at December&nbsp;31, 2015. We expect to maintain this relationship with the customer for the near term.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Borrowings
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	At December&nbsp;31, 2015, total borrowings consisted of FHLB advances of $72.0&nbsp;million and Debentures issued by the Company of
	$5.1&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2014, total borrowings consisted of advances from the FHLB of $86.0&nbsp;million and Debentures of $5.1&nbsp;million. During 2015, we repaid
	$14.0&nbsp;million of FHLB advances with proceeds from loan sales.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	weighted average cost of FHLB advances decreased 16 basis points from 2.31% at December&nbsp;31, 2014 to 2.15% at December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily due to maturities of $35.0&nbsp;million of
	FHLB advances with an average interest rate of 2.02% and new advances totaling $21.0&nbsp;million with an average interest rate of 1.24%.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	38
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Stockholders' Equity
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Stockholders' equity was $46.2&nbsp;million, or 11.46% of the Company's total assets, at December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to
	$37.3&nbsp;million, or 10.62% of the Company's total assets, at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase in stockholders' equity during 2015 was primarily due to net earnings for the year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our principal subsidiary, Broadway Federal, must comply with capital standards established by the OCC in the conduct of its business. Failure to
	comply with such capital requirements may result in significant limitations on its business or other sanctions. As a "small bank holding company", we are not subject to consolidated capital
	requirements under the new Basel III capital rules. The current regulatory capital requirements and possible consequences of failure to maintain compliance are described in Part&nbsp;I,
	Item&nbsp;1 "Business-Regulation" and in Note&nbsp;13 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liquidity
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The objective of liquidity management is to ensure that we have the continuing ability to fund operations and meet our obligations on a timely and
	cost-effective basis. The Bank's sources of funds include deposits, advances from the FHLB, other borrowings, proceeds from the sale of loans, REO, and investment securities, and payments of principal
	and interest on loans and investment securities. The Bank is currently approved by the FHLB to borrow up to 30% of total assets to the extent the Bank provides qualifying collateral and holds
	sufficient FHLB stock. This approved limit and collateral requirement would have permitted the Bank to borrow an additional $38.3&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. Also, the Bank received
	$2.5&nbsp;million cash from equity contributions by the Company during 2014. The Company did not make any capital contributions to the Bank during 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Bank's primary uses of funds include withdrawals of and interest payments on deposits, originations of loans, purchases of investment securities, and the payment of operating expenses. Also, when
	the Bank has more funds than required for reserve requirements or short-term liquidity needs, the Bank sells federal funds to the Federal Reserve Bank or other financial institutions. The Bank's
	liquid assets at December&nbsp;31, 2015 consisted of $67.8&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents and $13.4&nbsp;million in securities available-for-sale that were not pledged, compared to
	$20.8&nbsp;million in cash and cash equivalents and $15.9&nbsp;million in securities available-for-sale that were not pledged at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The high levels of liquid assets as of
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 primarily reflect the cash from new retail deposits. Currently, we believe that the Bank has sufficient liquidity to support growth over the foreseeable future.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company's liquidity, separate from the Bank, is based primarily on the proceeds from financing transactions, such as the private placements completed in August 2013 and October 2014. The Company
	has not been able to obtain funds from the Bank since 2010 as the Order, prior to its termination in November 2015, placed limitations on the Bank, including prohibition of the payment of dividends by
	the Bank without prior regulatory approval. The Bank is currently under no prohibition to
	pay dividends, but is subject to restrictions as to the amount of the dividends based on normal regulatory guidelines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company recorded consolidated net cash inflows from operating activities of $14.2&nbsp;million and $1.3&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Net
	cash inflows from operating activities during 2015 were primarily attributable to net proceeds from the sale of loans.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company recorded consolidated net cash outflows from investing activities of $7.9&nbsp;million and $54.4&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Net
	cash outflows from investing activities during 2015 were primarily attributable to the purchase of single-family loans during the fourth quarter.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	39
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=42,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=14402,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DW49801A.;18',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DW49801_1_40">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company recorded consolidated net cash inflows from financing activities of $40.7&nbsp;million and $15.7&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. Net
	cash inflows from financing activities during 2015 were primarily attributable to the increase in deposits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Off-Balance-Sheet Arrangements and Contractual Obligations
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We are party to financial instruments with off-balance-sheet risk in the normal course of our business, primarily in order to meet the financing
	needs of our customers. These instruments involve, to varying degrees, elements of credit, interest rate and liquidity risk. In accordance with GAAP, these instruments are either not recorded in the
	consolidated financial statements or are recorded in amounts that differ from the notional amounts. Such instruments primarily include lending commitments and lease commitments as described below.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Lending
	commitments include commitments to originate loans and to fund lines of credit. Commitments to extend credit are agreements to lend to a customer as long as there is no violation of any
	condition established in the commitment. Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates or other termination clauses and may require payment of a fee by the borrower. Since some of the commitments
	are expected to expire without being drawn upon, the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements. We evaluate creditworthiness on a case-by-case basis. Our maximum
	exposure to credit risk is represented by the contractual amount of the instruments.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	addition to our lending commitments, we have contractual obligations related to operating lease commitments. Operating lease commitments are obligations under various non-cancellable operating
	leases on buildings and land used for office space and banking purposes. The following table details our contractual obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_23"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:73%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Impact of Inflation and Changing Prices
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Our consolidated financial statements, including accompanying notes, have been prepared in accordance with GAAP which require the measurement of
	financial position and operating results primarily in terms of historical dollars without considering the changes in the relative purchasing power of money over time due to inflation. The impact of
	inflation is reflected in increased costs of our operations. Unlike industrial companies, nearly all of our assets and liabilities are monetary in nature. As a result, interest rates have a greater
	impact on our performance than do the effects of general levels of inflation. Interest rates do not necessarily move in the same direction or to the same extent as the price of goods and services.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Critical Accounting Policies
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Critical accounting policies are those that involve significant judgments and assessments by management, and which could potentially result in
	materially different results under
	different assumptions and conditions. This discussion highlights those accounting policies that management considers critical. All
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	40
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=43,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=812426,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DW49801A.;18',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DW49801_1_41">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	accounting
	policies are important, however, and therefore you are encouraged to review each of the policies included in Note&nbsp;1 "Summary of Significant Accounting Principles" of the Notes to
	Consolidated Financial Statements beginning at page&nbsp;F-8 to gain a better understanding of how our financial performance is measured and reported. Management has identified the Company's
	critical accounting policies as follows:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Allowance for Loan Losses
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The determination of the allowance for loan losses is considered critical due to the high degree of judgment involved, the subjectivity of the
	underlying assumptions used, and the potential for changes in the economic environment that could result in material changes in the amount of the allowance for loan losses considered necessary. The
	allowance is evaluated on a regular basis by management and the Board of Directors and is based on a periodic review of the collectability of the loans in light of historical experience, the nature
	and size of the loan portfolio, adverse situations that may affect borrowers' ability to repay, the estimated value of any underlying collateral, prevailing economic conditions and feedback from
	regulatory examinations. See Item&nbsp;1, "Business&nbsp;&#150; Asset Quality&nbsp;&#150; Allowance for Loan Losses" for a full discussion of the allowance for loan losses.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Real Estate Owned ("REO")
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	REO consists of property acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure and is recorded at the fair value, less estimated costs to sell,
	at the time of acquisition. The excess, if any, of the loan balance over the fair value of the property at the time of transfer from loans to REO is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
	Subsequent to the transfer to REO, if the fair value of the property less estimated selling costs declines to an amount less than the carrying value of the property, the deficiency is charged to
	income as a provision expense and a valuation allowance is established. Operating costs after acquisition are expensed as incurred. Due to changing market conditions, there are inherent uncertainties
	in the assumptions made with respect to the estimated fair
	value of REO. Therefore, the amount ultimately realized may differ from the amounts reflected in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Income Taxes
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined using the liability (or balance sheet) method. Under this method, the net deferred tax asset or
	liability is determined based on the tax effects of the temporary differences between the book and tax bases of the various balance sheet assets and liabilities and gives current recognition to
	changes in tax rates and laws. A valuation allowance is established against deferred tax assets when, based upon the available evidence including historical and projected taxable income, it is more
	likely than not that some or all of the deferred tax asset will not be realized. In assessing the realization of deferred tax assets, management evaluates both positive and negative evidence,
	including the existence of any cumulative losses in the current year and the prior two years, the amount of taxes paid in available carry-back years, forecasts of future income and available tax
	planning strategies. This analysis is updated quarterly. Based on this analysis, the Company anticipates partial realization of its net deferred tax assets and has reduced its valuation allowance to
	$2.5&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015. As a result, the Company reported $4.6&nbsp;million of net deferred tax assets at December&nbsp;31, 2015. The Company recorded a valuation
	allowance of $8.8&nbsp;million and $0 of net deferred tax assets at December&nbsp;31, 2014. See Note&nbsp;13 "Income Taxes" of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements in Item&nbsp;8,
	"Financial Statements and Supplementary Data."
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Fair Value Measurements
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Fair value is the exchange price that would be received for an asset or paid to transfer a liability (exit price) in the principal or most
	advantageous market for the asset or liability in an orderly transaction between
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	41
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=44,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=425081,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DW49801A.;18',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DW49801_1_42">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	market
	participants on the measurement date. There are three levels of inputs that may be used to measure fair values:
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Level&nbsp;1:
	Quoted prices (unadjusted) for identical assets or liabilities in active markets that the entity has the ability to access as of the measurement date.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Level&nbsp;2:
	Significant observable inputs other than Level&nbsp;1 prices such as quoted prices for similar assets or liabilities; quoted prices in markets that are not active; or other inputs
	that are observable or can be corroborated by observable market data.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Level&nbsp;3:
	Significant unobservable inputs that reflect a company's own assumptions about the assumptions that market participants would use in pricing an asset or liability.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Fair
	values are estimated using relevant market information and other assumptions, as more fully disclosed in Note&nbsp;5 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements. Fair value estimates
	involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment regarding interest rates, credit risk, prepayments, and other factors, especially in the absence of broad markets for particular items.
	Changes in assumptions or in market conditions could significantly affect the estimates.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_MANAGEMENTS_DISCUSSION>
<EFX_FINANCIAL_STATEMENTS>

<EFX_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES>
<A NAME="FIS_CONTROL_AND_PROCEDURES"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_DW49801_ITEM_9A__CONTROLS_AND_PROCEDURES">
</A>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_TOC_DW49801_3">
</A>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	ITEM 9A.&nbsp;&nbsp;CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Evaluation of disclosure controls and procedures
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	As of December&nbsp;31, 2015, an evaluation was performed under the supervision of the Company's Chief Executive Officer ("CEO") and Chief
	Financial Officer ("CFO") of the effectiveness of the design and operation of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures. Based on that evaluation, the Company's CEO and CFO concluded that the
	Company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Management's annual report on internal control over financial reporting
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The management of Broadway Financial Corporation is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting
	for the Company as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(f) under the Exchange Act. This system, which management has chosen to base on the framework set forth in
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Internal
	Control-Integrated Framework
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, published by the 1992 Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ("COSO"), and which is effected by the Company's Board of
	Directors, management and other personnel, is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external
	purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Company's internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1)&nbsp;pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly
	reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (2)&nbsp;provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial
	statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and the
	Directors of the Company; and
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	42
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=45,EFW="2227960",CP="BROADWAY FINANCIAL CORP.",DN="1",CHK=339247,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK123:[15ZCW1.15ZCW49801]DW49801A.;18',USER='DNICHOL',CD='28-MAR-2016;13:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DW49801_1_43">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227960Z10-K_HTM_BG49801A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	(3)&nbsp;provide
	reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the Company's assets that could have a material effect on the
	financial statements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Because
	of its inherent limitations, a system of internal control over financial reporting can provide only reasonable assurance and may not prevent or detect misstatements. Further, because of
	changes in conditions, effectiveness of internal controls over financial reporting may vary over time.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	With
	the participation of the Company's Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, management has conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Company's system of internal control
	over financial reporting. Based on this evaluation, management determined that the Company's system of internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	This
	annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company's registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting. Management's report was not subject to
	attestation by the Company's registered public accounting firm pursuant to rules of the Securities and Exchange Commission that permit the Company to provide only management's report in this annual
	report.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Changes in internal control over financial reporting
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	There were no significant changes in the Company's internal control over financial reporting identified in connection with the evaluation of internal
	control over financial reporting that occurred during the fourth quarter of 2015 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company's internal control over
	financial reporting.
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:80%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_SIGNATURES>
<EFX_AUDITORS_OPINION>
<A NAME="FIS_AUDITORS_OPINION"></A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_FC49801_REPORT_OF_INDEPENDENT___FC402286">
</A>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_TOC_FC49801_1">
</A>
<BR>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
	REPORT OF INDEPENDENT REGISTERED PUBLIC ACCOUNTING FIRM
<BR>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	The
	Board of Directors and Stockholders
<BR>
	Broadway Financial Corporation
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	have audited the accompanying consolidated statements of financial condition of Broadway Financial Corporation and Subsidiary (the "Company") as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, and the
	related consolidated statements of income and comprehensive income, changes in stockholders' equity and cash flows for the years then ended. These consolidated financial statements are the
	responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). Those standards require that we plan and perform the audits to obtain
	reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements are free of material misstatement. The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its
	internal control over financial reporting. Our audits included consideration of internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the
	circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Company's internal control over financial reporting. Accordingly, we express no such opinion. An audit also
	includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the consolidated financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made
	by management, as well as evaluating the overall consolidated financial statement presentation. We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	In
	our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the consolidated financial position of Broadway Financial Corporation and Subsidiary
	as of December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, and the consolidated results of their operations and their cash flows for the years then ended in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in
	the United States of America.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	/s/
	Moss Adams&nbsp;LLP
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	San
	Francisco, California
<BR>
	March&nbsp;28, 2016
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	F-1
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_FE49801_1_2">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->

<EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<A NAME="FIS_BALANCE_SHEET"></A>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;TEXT-ALIGN:JUSTIFY">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A NAME="A2227960Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_FM49801_1_8">
</A>
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"BLACK" -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;" -->

<!-- PARA=JUSTIFY -->
